lines.content: >"Coding is a mental construct, just think more computing thoughts" - Me
*PHI* frees your mind of having to remember things you need to do. It's
- encapsulates the very human touch of having somebody exasperated with your improper user inputs.
All you need to do is:
3. Do your stuff and watch it manage your tasks for you
Best part of all, it is completely **FREE** (~~unlike its creator's schedule~~)!
Look at all the things it can do:
- [x] Verbally abuse you if you fail to give proper inputs
- [ ] Reminders (that's a lie, I'm not doing that)
Since you're still here, here's a chunk of code for you to test out your coding abilities:

This is a project log for my individual project
- Chatbot was created and given the name Phi
- Greets the user and exits the program
- PHI now echoes commands entered by the user
- Exits when the user types the command _bye_
- Text entered by the user will be saved as a task
- Tasks are displayed in a list upon command _list_
- Tasks can now be marked as done (and undone)
- Tasks are now classified under one of three types:
- Deadlines: Tasks to be done before a specified deadline
- Events: Tasks that start and end at a specified time
- PHI can deal with basic-level errors (incorrect inputs) entered by the user
- Tasks can now be deleted from the list
- Tasks are saved in storage whenever any changes are made to the task list
- Data from the tasklist is loaded from the storage when PHI starts (_./data/tasklist.txt_)
- Deadline/Event dates can now be understood in yyyy-MM-dd format, and are displayed back as MMM dd yyyy
- Non-recognised formats will continue to be saved as a String
- Users can now find tasks by searching for a keyword
- Added Graphical User Interface (GUI) to the chatbot using JavaFX technology
- Testing of PHI is semi-automated through I/O redirection (text-ui-test)
- Enumerations used for the Tasks data-type
- Extraction of code as classes for more Object-Oriented-Programming (OOP)
- Creating/Refining the following classes (Ui, Storage, Parser, TaskList)
- Classes in PHI are organised into suitable java packages
- Currently, all classes are in one package (_phi_)
- Support for Gradle added to PHI, allowing automation of some build/run tasks
- JUnit tests created to test code behaviour
- PHI packaged into an executable JAR file (built using Gradle) for easier distribution
- JavaDoc header comments added to all classes and all non-trivial methods
- Code should now comply with the given coding standard for this project
- CheckStyle now incorporated to detect coding style violations. Configured to be used with Gradle
* A launcher class to workaround classpath issues.
* A GUI for Phi using FXML.
* Represents the core of the PHI chatbot. The root of the program will run from here.
* Constructor for a new instance of Phi
* Storage is loaded with the hardcoded file path of the .txt file
* Abstraction for the user-input handling process, which will continue running until the input "bye" is received
* Generates response to user input, and writes data to file after
* Represents the Deadline task type, and contains a String with a user-specified date as the deadline of a task
* Constructor for a new Deadline instance
* @param msg       Task message to be displayed
* @param isDone    Boolean determining if task is completed
public Deadline(String msg, boolean isDone, String deadline) {
//System.out.println("Can't find a proper date format, using deadline as a String");
return String.format("%s|%b|%s|%s", taskType.toString(), done, taskName, deadlineString);
* Represents the Event task type, and contains two Strings with user-specified dates as the start and end of a task
* Constructor for a new Event instance
* @param isDone    Boolean determining if task is completed
* @param start     User-specified start time of task
* @param end       User-specified end time of task
public Event(String msg, boolean isDone, String start, String end) {
//System.out.println("Can't find a proper date format, using /from input as a String");
//System.out.println("Can't find a proper date format, using /to input as a String");
return super.toString() + String.format(" (from: %s to: %s)", start, end);
return String.format("%s|%b|%s|%s|%s", taskType.toString(), done, taskName, start, end);
* Abstract parent class of all task types. Cannot be instantiated.
protected enum Type { T, D, E }
* @param taskType  Type of task (ToDo, Deadline, Event) in enumerated type
* @param done      Boolean determining if task is completed
* @param taskName  Task message to be displayed
public Task(Type taskType, boolean done, String taskName) {
* Returns the task in a String, formatted in the style that will be written to storage
* @return String representation of the task in output format
* Constructor for a new ToDo instance
* @param msg       Task message to be displayed
* @param isDone    Boolean determining if task is completed
* An example of a custom control using FXML.
* This control represents a dialog box consisting of an ImageView to represent the speaker's face and a label
* Flips the dialog box such that the ImageView is on the left and text on the right.
public static DialogBox getUserDialog(String text, Image img) {
public static DialogBox getPhiDialog(String text, Image img) {
* Controller for MainWindow. Provides the layout for the other controls.
private final Ui ui = new Ui();
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing PHI's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
PauseTransition pause = new PauseTransition(Duration.seconds(1)); // 1 second delay
// Close the JavaFX application after the delay
String greetingMsg = "Hellos! I'm PHI (Programmed Human Interaction)\nWhat can I do for you?\n";
* List of all accepted user commands
+ "1. list (prints out a list of all tasks)\n"
+ "3. deadline [TASK] /by [yyyy-MM-dd] (creates a corresponding deadline with body \"TASK\")\n"
+ "5. mark [X] (marks task X in the list)\n"
+ "6. unmark [X] (unmarks task X in the list)\n"
+ "7. delete [X] (removes task X from the list)\n"
+ "8. find [KEYWORD] (searches for tasks that contain corresponding KEYWORD)\n"
* Represents the handling of user-commands and making sense of them
* Method that handles parsing user inputs into its respective commands. Helps to check for user-input errors.
* String output will be handled by the function caller (PHI)
* @return      Response of the parser to the input, to be printed by PHI
return ("Nice job did you mean \"list\" coz what you gave wasn't an accepted input");
return "You gotta put an actual message in...";
return String.format("Hey nice job, did you mean \"todo %s\"...", input.substring(4));
return "You gotta put an actual message in...";
return String.format("Hey genius, did you mean \"deadline %s\"...", input.substring(8));
return "Look at which moron didn't add a deadline with the \"/by\" flag";
return "Come on you have to fill in something...";
return "Hey you have to give me a deadline!";
return "You gotta put an actual message in...";
return String.format("Hey genius, did you mean \"event %s\"...", input.substring(5));
return "Congratulations you're the only idiot who would leave out both \"/from\" and \"/to\" flags";
return "Please put the \"/from\" flag before the \"/to\" flag, thanksss";
return "Come on you have to fill in something...";
return "Your \"/from\" flag can't be empty! Leave a space if you want it blank.";
return "Your \"/to\" flag can't be empty! Leave a space if you want it blank.";
return tasks.addTask(new Event(taskMsg, false, fromStr, toStr));
return "You gotta put something for me to find...";
return ("SIKE I can't process that! Try again or say \"help\" to see a list of all available commands");
* Represents all storage-related methods (reading from file, checking file paths etc.)
* Constructor for a new Storage instance.
* If file / file path does not exist, the .txt file and corresponding directories will be created.
* @param pathString File path for the saved tasklist.txt file (to be read and written to)
System.out.println("No file found, new .txt file created!");
* Reads the input of the stored tasklist .txt file and returns the saved information
* @return TaskList object containing the tasks stored in tasklist.txt
System.out.println("Text file has been scanned!\n" + tasks.getSize() + " items in the list");
System.out.println("Something went wrong... There's still no file to be found");
* Writes the output of PHI's current tasklist to the .txt file in storage.
* Represents the task list of the chatbot
throw new IllegalArgumentException("this task does not exist, genius..");
* Marks a task as done and returns the corresponding response message
* Contains error handling for incorrect user inputs
* @param input User-inputted string to be parsed
return "ALRIGHT NICE I'll mark this as completed :)\n" + t;
return "OI open ur eyes and give a proper input ITS \"mark\" AND A NUMBER";
* Marks a task as undone and returns the corresponding response message
* Contains error handling for incorrect user inputs
* @param input User-inputted string to be parsed
return "Oh nooo I will mark this undone then :(\n" + t;
return "OI open ur eyes and give a proper input ITS \"unmark\" AND A NUMBER";
* Adds a task to the TaskList
* Deletes a task from the list and returns the corresponding response message
* Contains error handling for incorrect user inputs
* @param input User-inputted string to be parsed
System.out.printf("Alright say bye bye to task %d!%n", number);
return String.format("There's %d task(s) in the list now.%n", tasks.size());
return "Ugh to delete stuff, you have to input \"delete\" and the number...";
* Prints the current task list. If list is empty, returns a corresponding response message
return "You do know that to SHOW a list there has to be stuff INSIDE the (currently empty) list right?";
* Adds a task into the list from input given by the stored tasklist.txt file
* @param input each individual line of input in the .txt file
* Returns the entire tasklist in output format, to be written by a Storage object.
* @return A String containing the entire task list, formatted in output style.
* Returns the list of all tasks that match the given String keyword
* @param searchString Keyword to be searched for
* @return             Concatenated String of all tasks containing argument keyword
StringBuilder output = new StringBuilder("Here's all the tasks that match your keyword!\n");
